mechanoreception.notes: As sponges, Leucopsacidae likely possess mechanoreceptors to detect water currents and other physical stimuli. This is inferred due to the general body plan of sponges and their dependence on water flow for feeding and gas exchange.

chemoreception.notes: Sponges rely on chemoreception to detect dissolved substances in the water, aiding in filter feeding and other physiological processes. This is inferred due to the general body plan of sponges and their dependence on water flow for feeding.

photoreception.notes: The presence or absence of photoreception in Leucopsacidae is currently unknown. While some sponges are known to possess light-sensitive cells, it is unclear if this is a common feature across all glass sponges or specifically within this family.
